title: 2 letterpress types: Italic and blackletter
content:
Can someone name these typefaces?

[http://www.hs-augsburg.de/~linke/Type%20Identification/schrift1.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202140119/http:/www.hs-augsburg.de/~linke/Type%20Identification/schrift1.jpg "http://www.hs-augsburg.de/~linke/Type%20Identification/schrift1.jpg")  
 [http://www.hs-augsburg.de/~linke/Type%20Identification/schrift2.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202140119/http:/www.hs-augsburg.de/~linke/Type%20Identification/schrift2.jpg "http://www.hs-augsburg.de/~linke/Type%20Identification/schrift2.jpg")

Thanks for any help!  
oliver
author: lazydog

comments.content:
Can you help us with any information or guesses you have about the origin and age of these typefaces?

- Mike Yanega

I'ver never seen these strange fonts. But I'm sure, I'ld remember  
Are you sure, this are fonts? Lead letter press fonts or digital ones?  
The A of the Antiqua Variante is not very unsusual, but the capital E, F are.

And the second one looks like what a digital typographist may have thought about a Kanzlei Gothic.

Need more information. All, what you know about were these fonts are coming from.

Georg  
\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
„Ich bin ein Preuße, kennt Ihr meine Farben...“

Hello Oliver,  
the Italic is _Recta Kursiv_ (H. Berthold 1926). A sample can be found in [Global Type’s Digitalem Seemann](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202140119/http:/www.global-type.org/Schriften.567.0.html).  
F

Florian, I could not find that on that site. Does that typeface have a Roman version?

- Mike Yanega

No, it seems it was published as a standalone Italic. Try this (English language) link: [http://www.global-type.org/Searching.743.0.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202140119/http:/www.global-type.org/Searching.743.0.html "http://www.global-type.org/Searching.743.0.html")  
Alas, Global Type doesn’t allow direct links. You have to enter ‘Recta’ into the ‘Name’ field, it’s the only hit that has an image. Not much information, though.

The [pdf on H. Berthold types](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202140119/http:/www.klingspor-museum.de/KlingsporKuenstler/Schriftgiessereien/Berthold/BertholdAG.pdf) by Klingspor Museum confirms that there was a Recta-Kursiv published in 1926 – but it has no sample.  
F

Here's a small sample of Recta-Kursiv.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202140119im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Recta-Kursiv_4540.jpg)

bist n schatz, florian, danke!

sorry for not answering earlier... but for those who are still trying to find the blackletter: both typefaces are from a letterpress printing shop here in munich. i don't know anything about their age or provenance. no casting marks either...

oliver

You’re welcome.  
For the Textura: I assume you’re not looking for a digitally available approximation, but for an actual ID.  
Still, I found one in [Fraktur Mon Amour](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202140119/http:/www.fraktur-mon-amour.de/de/) that comes pretty close, in overall style:  
 [Blackletter Extra Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202140119/http:/www.moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/samples/b/blackletter.htm)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100202140119im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Blackletter-ExtraBold_5760.gif)
  
F

yes, i'm looking for the actual id, not digital "approximations". i already found similar faces like mediaeval gotisch (genzsch & heyse; cf. global type), but not this one...

i updated the image with some more letters (upper case and figures). especially the caps might help, as they are built more like initials.

oliver
